thread.title: Horsley Park house sells for $855k above reserve
thread.title_full: Horsley Park house sells for $855k above reserve

author: Aidan Devine
title: Horsley Park house sells for $855k above reserve
text:
ITS decor harks back to the 1960s and its front garden is a sprawling mess of weeds and uncut grass, yet a three-bedroom home near Fairfield in Sydney’s west sold at auction last night for $855,000 more than its sellers would have accepted.
99-107 Abbotsbury Dr was advertised as in “original” condition. Source: Supplied
The brick house at 99-107 Abbotsbury Drive in Horsley Park sold for more than $3.2 million, well above the vendors’ $2.35 million reserve, which was already almost double the suburb’s median house price of $1.4 million. The $3.2 million purchase price was almost $2 million above the area’s median house price. Source: Supplied
“The whole room cheered when the final bid came in,” said the home’s auctioneer Rocky Bartolotto. “It was a simply amazing result and surpassed everyone’s expectations.” The home is situated on an elevated 2ha block close to the M7 and attracted a lot of attention when it first hit the market due to a shortage of property listings in the area, selling agent Charlie Cini of United Realty Acreage and Residential said.
28 parties registered to bid at the auction. Source: Supplied
Close to 30 parties registered for bidding and a large crowd of local residents gathered to watch the potential buyers battle it out. Bidding had started at $1.1 million, but two determined bidders drove the price past $3 million, until a third buyer, who hadn’t participated in bidding until that point, entered the fray.
“It was almost like he came out of nowhere,” said an onlooker. “The other two bidders had been fighting it out between themselves, but he came and blew them out the water.”
Mr Cini said the final result was proof that the local region is still producing big sales results.
“We had been expecting around $2.5 million, but the market has spoken,” he said.
It is not yet clear what the new owner intends to do with the property.
Originally published as Would you pay $855k extra for this?
